**Francis J.** "**Frank** " **Underwood** is a fictional character and the
protagonist/anti-hero of the American adaptation of _[House of
Cards](/wiki/House_of_Cards_\(U.S._TV_series\) "House of Cards \(U.S. TV
series\)")_. He is portrayed by [Kevin Spacey](/wiki/Kevin_Spacey "Kevin
Spacey"). He is based on [Francis Urquhart](/wiki/Francis_Urquhart "Francis
Urquhart"), the protagonist of the British novel and television series _[House
of Cards](/wiki/House_of_Cards_\(UK_TV_series\) "House of Cards \(UK TV
series\)")_ , from which the American [Netflix](/wiki/Netflix "Netflix")
series is drawn. He is married to [Claire Underwood](/wiki/Claire_Underwood
"Claire Underwood") ([Robin Wright](/wiki/Robin_Wright "Robin Wright")), but
also had a sexual relationship with Zoe Barnes ([Kate Mara](/wiki/Kate_Mara
"Kate Mara")) in [season 1](/wiki/House_of_Cards_\(season_1\) "House of Cards
\(season 1\)"). He made his first appearance in the series' [pilot
episode](/wiki/Pilot_episode "Pilot episode"), "[Chapter
1](/wiki/Chapter_1_\(House_of_Cards\) "Chapter 1 \(House of Cards\)")".

Underwood is from [Gaffney, South Carolina](/wiki/Gaffney,_South_Carolina
"Gaffney, South Carolina"). He graduated from The Sentinel (a fictionalized
version of [The Citadel, The Military College of South
Carolina](/wiki/The_Citadel,_The_Military_College_of_South_Carolina "The
Citadel, The Military College of South Carolina")) in 1981 and, subsequently,
[Harvard Law School](/wiki/Harvard_Law_School "Harvard Law School") in 1984.
Some of Underwood's dialogue throughout the series is presented in a direct
address to the audience, a narrative technique that breaks the [fourth
wall](/wiki/Fourth_wall "Fourth wall"). The character speaks with a [Southern
accent](/wiki/Southern_American_English "Southern American English"). During
season 1, he is the [Democratic](/wiki/Democratic_Party_\(United_States\)
"Democratic Party \(United States\)") [Majority
Whip](/wiki/House_Majority_Whip "House Majority Whip") in the [United States
House of Representatives](/wiki/United_States_House_of_Representatives "United
States House of Representatives"). In [season
2](/wiki/House_of_Cards_\(season_2\) "House of Cards \(season 2\)"), he is the
newly appointed [Vice President of the United
States](/wiki/Vice_President_of_the_United_States "Vice President of the
United States"), before becoming [President of the United
States](/wiki/President_of_the_United_States "President of the United States")
in the season finale.

Underwood has been described as manipulative, conniving,
[Machiavellian](/wiki/Machiavellianism "Machiavellianism"),
[sociopathic](/wiki/Antisocial_personality_disorder "Antisocial personality
disorder"), and a symbol of political corruption and evil. Throughout the
series, he manipulates and destroys several people, including those he calls
friends, for his own ends. Among other crimes, he personally commits murder
twice, signs off on another murder committed by a subordinate, orders the
deaths of two former employees, critically injures a member of his cabinet to
prevent her testifying against him, and [indirectly allows for murder of a
civilian for political ends](/wiki/False_flag "False flag").

Spacey has received positive reviews for his portrayal of Frank Underwood, but
the character itself has been criticized for its repetitive nature[1][2] and
one-dimensionality.[3][4] Spacey shared the distinction of being among the
first three leading web-television roles to be nominated for [Primetime Emmy
Awards](/wiki/Primetime_Emmy_Award "Primetime Emmy Award") at the [65th
Primetime Emmy Awards](/wiki/65th_Primetime_Emmy_Awards "65th Primetime Emmy
Awards"). Spacey has also been nominated for two [Golden Globe
Awards](/wiki/Golden_Globe_Award "Golden Globe Award"), winning one, and five
[Screen Actors Guild Awards](/wiki/Screen_Actors_Guild_Award "Screen Actors
Guild Award"), including two cast nominations and including two wins, for his
performance.

## Background and
description[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Frank_Underwood_\(House_of_Cards\)&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Background and description")]

### Early
life[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Frank_Underwood_\(House_of_Cards\)&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Early life")]

Francis J. Underwood was born on November 5, 1959, to Catherine and Calvin T.
Underwood in [Gaffney, South Carolina](/wiki/Gaffney,_South_Carolina "Gaffney,
South Carolina"). He is an only child.[5] He was raised in impoverished
circumstances, with the threat of bank foreclosure on the farm they lived on.
He entered The Sentinel, a military school in [Charleston, South
Carolina](/wiki/Charleston,_South_Carolina "Charleston, South Carolina"),
loosely based on [The Citadel, The Military College of South
Carolina](/wiki/The_Citadel,_The_Military_College_of_South_Carolina "The
Citadel, The Military College of South Carolina"), in the fall of 1976. He
graduated in 1981 and, despite having made poor grades, gained admittance into
[Harvard Law School](/wiki/Harvard_Law_School "Harvard Law School"). He
graduated from there in 1984.[5][6][7] While at the Sentinel, he had a
[homosexual](/wiki/Homosexual "Homosexual") relationship with his roommate,
Tim Corbet, which lasted until his first year of law school. Underwood was
raised Christian but holds God in complete contempt.[8]

###
Family[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Frank_Underwood_\(House_of_Cards\)&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Family")]

Underwood's great-great-great-grandfather, Corporal Augustus Elijah Underwood,
was a [Confederate](/wiki/Confederate_States_of_America "Confederate States of
America") soldier who served in the 12th [South Carolina](/wiki/South_Carolina
"South Carolina") [Infantry](/wiki/Infantry "Infantry")
[Regiment](/wiki/Regiment "Regiment") of McGowan's Brigade at the [Battle of
Spotsylvania](/wiki/Battle_of_Spotsylvania_Court_House "Battle of Spotsylvania
Court House"). He served at the Bloody Angle on May 12, 1864, during the
[Civil War](/wiki/American_Civil_War "American Civil War") and was killed by a
bludgeon to the back of the head from his own regiment during the middle of
the night. Underwood is fascinated by his ancestry. When Underwood falls into
a coma following an assassination attempt, Augustus appears in several of his
hallucinations. However, he dismisses the Confederacy as weak and calls their
cause of preserving the institution of slavery "asinine". His great-great
grandfather was two when Augustus was killed.[9]

His father, Calvin T. Underwood, was a peach farmer in his home town of
Gaffney who died at the age of 43 of a heart attack. The Underwoods lived in
poverty, and nearly lost the farm when Frank was a child; to get a bank loan
and avoid foreclosure, his father attended a meeting of the [Ku Klux
Klan](/wiki/Ku_Klux_Klan "Ku Klux Klan"), of which the bank manager was a
member. Underwood speaks fondly of his father in public,[10] but this is a
political ploy; in his asides to the audience, Underwood describes his father
as a weak man who accomplished nothing with his life.[11] He even urinates on
his father's grave in season 3. Despite disliking his father, however,
Underwood was influenced by him.[12] Calvin was an abusive
[alcoholic](/wiki/Alcoholic "Alcoholic") and caused his wife and son years of
misery. Underwood has said that when he was 13, he walked in on his father
putting a shotgun in his mouth. Calvin asked him to pull the trigger, which he
refused to do. He has stated that his biggest regret is not killing his father
when he had the chance.[13]

### Political
career[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Frank_Underwood_\(House_of_Cards\)&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Political career")]

#### South Carolina
Legislature[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Frank_Underwood_\(House_of_Cards\)&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: South Carolina Legislature")]

Underwood was elected at the age of 25 to the [South Carolina State
Senate](/wiki/South_Carolina_Senate "South Carolina Senate") as one of the
youngest members in the state's legislative history after graduating from
[Harvard](/wiki/Harvard_University "Harvard University") in 1984. He was re-
elected to the state senate at 29 in 1988 for his second, and last, term as a
State [Senator](/wiki/Senate "Senate").

#### Congressional
Election[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Frank_Underwood_\(House_of_Cards\)&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Congressional Election")]

Underwood was elected to the [U.S. House of
Representatives](/wiki/United_States_House_of_Representatives "United States
House of Representatives") in 1990 as a
[Democratic](/wiki/Democratic_Party_\(United_States\) "Democratic Party
\(United States\)") representative for the [5th Congressional District of
South Carolina](/wiki/South_Carolina%27s_5th_congressional_district "South
Carolina's 5th congressional district"), being sworn in during January 1991.
He won another 11 consecutive elections, winning his final term in 2012. He
was elected [Whip](/wiki/Whip_\(politics\) "Whip \(politics\)") for the
Democratic Party in 2005, serving as [House Majority
Whip](/wiki/Party_leaders_of_the_United_States_House_of_Representatives "Party
leaders of the United States House of Representatives") between 2005 and 2013.

Often, Underwood's thoughts throughout the series are presented in a direct
address to the audience, a narrative technique known as breaking the [fourth
wall](/wiki/Fourth_wall "Fourth wall").[14] Immediately prior to starring in
_House of Cards_ , Spacey had starred in a production of [William
Shakespeare](/wiki/William_Shakespeare "William Shakespeare")'s _[Richard
III](/wiki/Richard_III_\(play\) "Richard III \(play\)")_ as [Richard III of
England](/wiki/Richard_III_of_England "Richard III of England"),[14][15] a
character that serves as a partial basis for both Urquhart and Underwood.[16]
His last name is derived from [Oscar Underwood](/wiki/Oscar_Underwood "Oscar
Underwood"), who served as the first Democratic [House Minority
Whip](/wiki/House_Minority_Whip "House Minority Whip") from about 1900 to
1901.[17] His few vices include smoking cigarettes and playing [video
games](/wiki/Video_games "Video games");[18] when the Secret Service cuts off
his online gaming service after he becomes Vice President, he takes up
creating model figurines.

Spacey viewed portraying Underwood for a second season as a continuing
learning process. "There is so much I don’t know about Francis, so much that
I'm learning... I've always thought that the profession closest to that of an
actor is being a detective... We are given clues by writers... Then you lay
them all out and try to make them come alive as a character who’s complex and
surprising, maybe even to yourself."[19]

Underwood's sexuality is ambiguous throughout much of the first two seasons;
he has sexual liaisons with both men and women, but he is never explicitly
identified by any sexual label. Before Season 2, various sources speculated
about his homosexuality. It is revealed in "Chapter 8" he had an experience
with homosexuality in college.[20] Underwood and Claire are never depicted
having sex in season 1.[20] _[Slate](/wiki/Slate_\(magazine\) "Slate
\(magazine\)")_ journalist [Hanna Rosin](/wiki/Hanna_Rosin "Hanna Rosin")
noted: if Frank and Claire Underwood were a real-life Washington couple and
they were found each to be having an affair, he would be accused of being
"secretly gay, turned on by women only when he can use them for a pure power
play".[21] Other sources make no definite stance on Underwood's sexuality, but
hypothesize that he is not sexually attracted to Claire.[22] In season 2,
Underwood is involved in a [threesome](/wiki/Threesome "Threesome") with
Claire and Secret Service agent Edward Meechum ([Nathan
Darrow](/wiki/Nathan_Darrow "Nathan Darrow")),[23] while in season 3, there is
a moment of sexual tension between Underwood and his biographer, Tom Yates
([Paul Sparks](/wiki/Paul_Sparks "Paul Sparks")). The same season, however,
also features the only scene in the series in which Underwood and Claire have
sex exclusively with each other. In season five, he has sex with Eric Rawlings
([Malcolm Madera](/w/index.php?title=Malcolm_Madera&action=edit&redlink=1
"Malcolm Madera \(page does not exist\)")), his male personal trainer.

According to _[Time](/wiki/Time_\(magazine\) "Time \(magazine\)")_ television
critic [James Poniewozik](/wiki/James_Poniewozik "James Poniewozik"), by the
end of the first episode, it becomes clear that Underwood both literally and
figuratively uses meat as his metaphor of choice. He may begin a day with a
celebratory rack of ribs, because "I'm feelin' hungry today!", and he depicts
his life with meat metaphors. For example, he describes the White House Chief
of Staff with grudging admiration: "She’s as tough as a two-dollar steak" and
plans to destroy an enemy the way "you devour a whale. One bite at a time". He
also endures a tedious weekly meeting with House leaders, as he tells the
audience, by "[imagining] their lightly salted faces frying in a skillet."[24]

Tim Goodman of _[The Hollywood Reporter](/wiki/The_Hollywood_Reporter "The
Hollywood Reporter")_ notes that, in Season 2, with Underwood's new position
as Vice President, "He's got more power now and that means he instills more
fear in his enemies".[25] At one point during the season, he states "The road
to power is paved with hypocrisy and casualties. I need to prove what the vice
president is capable of."[26] Underwood and Claire "continue their ruthless
rise to power as threats mount on all fronts."[27]

### Underwood vs.
Urquhart[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Frank_Underwood_\(House_of_Cards\)&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Underwood vs. Urquhart")]

Underwood is an Americanized version of the original BBC series lead character
[Francis Urquhart](/wiki/Francis_Urquhart "Francis Urquhart"), a
[Machiavellian](/wiki/Machiavellianism "Machiavellianism") post-[Margaret
Thatcher](/wiki/Margaret_Thatcher "Margaret Thatcher") [Chief Whip of the
Conservative Party](/wiki/Chief_Whip_of_the_Conservative_Party "Chief Whip of
the Conservative Party"). Urquhart employs deceit, cunning, murder, and
blackmail to influence and pursue the office of [Prime Minister of the United
Kingdom](/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_the_United_Kingdom "Prime Minister of the
United Kingdom"). According to series producer [Beau
Willimon](/wiki/Beau_Willimon "Beau Willimon"), the change in last name
stemmed from the "[Dickensian](/wiki/Dickensian "Dickensian")" feeling and
"more legitimately American" sounding resonance of the name 'Underwood'.
Whereas Urquhart is an aristocrat by birth, Underwood is a [self-made
man](/wiki/Self-made_man "Self-made man"), having been born into a poor
Southern family with an alcoholic father.[28] Urquhart was one of television's
first [antiheroes](/wiki/Antihero "Antihero"),[16] whereas Underwood follows
the more recent rash of antiheroes that includes [Tony
Soprano](/wiki/Tony_Soprano "Tony Soprano") of _[The
Sopranos](/wiki/The_Sopranos "The Sopranos")_ , [Walter
White](/wiki/Walter_White_\(Breaking_Bad\) "Walter White \(Breaking Bad\)") of
_[Breaking Bad](/wiki/Breaking_Bad "Breaking Bad")_ , and [Dexter
Morgan](/wiki/Dexter_Morgan "Dexter Morgan") of
_[Dexter](/wiki/Dexter_\(TV_series\) "Dexter \(TV series\)")_.[15] However,
unlike most other antiheroes, Underwood is not forced into immorality either
by circumstance (White), birth (Soprano) or upbringing (Morgan). In his review
of Season 2, _[Slant Magazine](/wiki/Slant_Magazine "Slant Magazine")_ 's Alan
Jones writes that Underwood is evil by choice.[29] Although the character is
based on the BBC show's lead character, in interviews during the writing and
filming of [season 2](/wiki/House_of_Cards_\(season_2\) "House of Cards
\(season 2\)"), creator and showrunner Willimon said that he used [Lyndon B.
Johnson](/wiki/Lyndon_B._Johnson "Lyndon B. Johnson") as a source of themes
and issues addressed in _House of Cards_.[30] Unlike the [right-
wing](/wiki/Political_right "Political right") Urquhart, who leads the
[Conservative Party](/wiki/Conservative_Party_\(UK\) "Conservative Party
\(UK\)"), the [center-left](/wiki/Center-left "Center-left") Underwood is a
member of the Democratic Party, but cares little for ideology in favor of
"ruthless pragmatism" in furthering his own political influence and power.[5]

### Relationship with Claire
Underwood[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Frank_Underwood_\(House_of_Cards\)&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Relationship with Claire Underwood")]

Stelter described Frank and Claire Underwood as a "scheming" couple.[31]
[Michael Dobbs](/wiki/Michael_Dobbs "Michael Dobbs"), the author of the
trilogy of novels upon which the British miniseries is based, compares the
compelling nature of their relationship favorably to the characters in the
original miniseries, and likens them to [Macbeth](/wiki/Macbeth_\(character\)
"Macbeth \(character\)") and [Lady Macbeth](/wiki/Lady_Macbeth "Lady
Macbeth").[16] Underwood has strong feelings for Claire, and frequently plots
with her at night. He says, "I love that woman. I love her more than sharks
love blood."[32] While Underwood is Machiavellian, Claire, like [Lady
Macbeth](/wiki/Lady_Macbeth "Lady Macbeth"), encourages her husband to do
whatever is necessary to seize power.[33][34] [Hank
Stuever](/wiki/Hank_Stuever "Hank Stuever") of _[The Washington
Post](/wiki/The_Washington_Post "The Washington Post")_ describes her as an
ice-queen wife.[35] She encourages his vices while noting her disapproval of
his weakness, saying, "My husband doesn’t apologize... even to me."[34] Her
overt encouragement gives a credibility to their symbiosis.[24] Smith says
"The Underwoods have proven themselves ruthless, manipulative, and robotic in
their pursuit and lust of power."[36] Upon viewing a four-episode preview of
season 2, Goodman says the series "...sells husband and wife power-at-all-
costs couple...as a little too oily and reptilian for anyone's good."[25]
Willimon notes that "What's extraordinary about Frank and Claire is there is
deep love and mutual respect, but the way they achieve this is by operating on
a completely different set of rules than the rest of us typically do."[37]
_[Los Angeles Times](/wiki/Los_Angeles_Times "Los Angeles Times")_ critic Mary
McNamara makes the case that _House of Cards_ is a love story on many levels,
but most importantly between Underwood and Claire. It is a story about a man
who will commit any crime imaginable while in pursuit of power and a political
wife who gives him the encouragement to pursue that power.[38]

Underwood and Claire engage in a threesome with their Secret Service bodyguard
Edward Meechum at one point in season 2, but have otherwise largely given up
intramarital and extramarital sex in favor of their pursuit of power.
_[International Business Times](/wiki/International_Business_Times
"International Business Times")_ critic Ellen Killoran notes that this may
relate back to Underwood's quotation of [Oscar Wilde](/wiki/Oscar_Wilde "Oscar
Wilde") to Zoe Barnes in Season 1: "A great man once said, 'everything is
about sex _except_ sex. Sex is about _power_.'" Avoiding sex may retain the
balance of power in their relationship.[39] His relationship with Claire is
the epicenter of season 2.[40]

### Relationship with Zoe
Barnes[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Frank_Underwood_\(House_of_Cards\)&action=edit&section=9
"Edit section: Relationship with Zoe Barnes")]

Underwood develops an intimate relationship with _Washington Herald_ and
_Slugline_ reporter Zoe Barnes ([Kate Mara](/wiki/Kate_Mara "Kate Mara")),
with Claire's knowledge.[28] As the show begins, Barnes is desperate to rise
from covering the Fairfax County Council beat to covering what's going on
"behind the veil of power in the Capitol hallways."[35] By the end of the
first episode, Barnes is among the cadre of Underwood's accomplices. They
begin a relationship, with Barnes promising to earn his trust and not "ask any
questions" in return for his supplying her with sensitive political
information.[34] Toward the end of Season 1, she ends their personal
relationship and begins investigating his connection to Congressman Peter
Russo's apparent suicide (Underwood had in fact killed him by locking him in
his car in a closed garage).[36] Underwood ultimately kills Barnes in the
season 2 premiere, by pushing her in front of an oncoming [Washington
Metro](/wiki/Washington_Metro "Washington Metro") train after she begins to
follow clues related to the murder.[41]

### Relationship with Edward
Meechum[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Frank_Underwood_\(House_of_Cards\)&action=edit&section=10
"Edit section: Relationship with Edward Meechum")]

Underwood is fond of the head of his Secret Service detail, Edward Meechum
([Nathan Darrow](/wiki/Nathan_Darrow "Nathan Darrow")), and it is hinted
several times that they harbor unacknowledged sexual feelings for each other.
When Meechum stumbles upon Underwood watching pornography, Underwood and
Claire joke about there being sexual chemistry between the two men. Shortly
after Underwood becomes vice president, he, Claire and Meechum have a
[threesome](/wiki/Threesome "Threesome").

Meechum remains Underwood's bodyguard once he becomes the president, and there
does not appear to be any continuing sexual relationship. Meechum remains
fiercely loyal, however; he warns Underwood's biographer Tom Yates ([Paul
Sparks](/wiki/Paul_Sparks "Paul Sparks")) not to write anything that would
damage Underwood's reputation. In season 4, Underwood traces Meechum's hand
with a marker on one of the walls of the White House when he wants to replace
a Confederate painting; Meechum suggests he put up something he likes instead.

When Lucas Goodwin shoots Underwood during a campaign event, Meechum trades
fire with the assassin, and both are killed instantly. Meechum's death is one
of the tragedies Claire mentions in a press briefing for a gun control bill
she is sponsoring, and Underwood has him buried in [Arlington National
Cemetery](/wiki/Arlington_National_Cemetery "Arlington National Cemetery"), a
rare privilege for a Secret Service agent, though Meechum may have been
eligible, in his own right, as a former member of the US Military who served
in Afghanistan. When Underwood recovers and finds that Meechum's hand tracing
has been painted over, he expresses grief and regret at the loss to Claire,
who says that Meechum was one of the few people who truly understood them.

### Breaking the fourth
wall[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Frank_Underwood_\(House_of_Cards\)&action=edit&section=11
"Edit section: Breaking the fourth wall")]

Spacey summed up Underwood's relationship with the viewer - i.e. whenever he
breaks [the fourth wall](/wiki/Meta-reference "Meta-reference") \- as being
like that of a "best friend" and "the person [he trusts] more than
anyone."[42] Because of this, his asides to the viewer serves as an indication
of Underwood's true feelings and intentions - typically when he is feigning
politeness and courtesy to people whom he despises. In the season 2 premiere,
after having gone the whole episode without doing so, Underwood addresses the
viewer directly, saying, "Did you think I had forgotten you? Perhaps you hoped
I had."[36] In addition, in season 3, after an argument with Claire that ends
with her storming out on him, a seething Frank vents his anger by lashing out
at the viewer; looking directly into the camera, he snaps "What're you lookin'
at?!" For the first four seasons, Underwood was the only character to break
the fourth wall until the very end of the fourth season, during which his wife
Claire - though silent - addresses the camera directly with Frank.[43]

##
Biography[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Frank_Underwood_\(House_of_Cards\)&action=edit&section=12
"Edit section: Biography")]

### Season
1[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Frank_Underwood_\(House_of_Cards\)&action=edit&section=13
"Edit section: Season 1")]

Main article: [House of Cards (season 1)](/wiki/House_of_Cards_\(season_1\)
"House of Cards \(season 1\)")

"Power is a lot like real estate. It’s all about location, location, location.
The closer you are to the source, the higher your property value."

— Underwood[7]

At the start of the show, Underwood is a Democratic Majority Whip in the House
of Representatives, where he has represented [South Carolina's 5th
congressional district](/wiki/South_Carolina%27s_5th_congressional_district
"South Carolina's 5th congressional district") since 1990.[5][44][45]

Underwood is passed over for an appointment as [United States Secretary of
State](/wiki/United_States_Secretary_of_State "United States Secretary of
State") even though he had been promised the position after ensuring the
election of [Colorado Governor](/wiki/Governor_of_Colorado "Governor of
Colorado") Garrett Walker ([Michel Gill](/wiki/Michel_Gill "Michel Gill")) as
President. Walker's Chief of Staff Linda Vasquez ([Sakina
Jaffrey](/wiki/Sakina_Jaffrey "Sakina Jaffrey")) gives him this news prior to
the January 2013 [United States presidential
inauguration](/wiki/United_States_presidential_inauguration "United States
presidential inauguration"). With the aid of Claire, and his fiercely loyal
Chief of Staff Doug Stamper ([Michael
Kelly](/wiki/Michael_Kelly_\(American_actor\) "Michael Kelly \(American
actor\)")), Underwood uses his position as House Whip to seek retribution. He
quickly allies with _Washington Herald_ reporter Zoe Barnes ([Kate
Mara](/wiki/Kate_Mara "Kate Mara")), whom he uses to undermine his rivals via
the press.[45][46] The viciousness of Underwood's manipulations escalates over
the course of the season.[15] He befriends Pennsylvania Rep. Peter Russo
([Corey Stoll](/wiki/Corey_Stoll "Corey Stoll")), encouraging him to quit
drinking and run for Governor of Pennsylvania; then his underlings create
enough pressure in the race to push Russo into publicly falling off the wagon
and ruining his career. Underwood finally murders him and makes it look like
suicide. He persuades Vice President Jim Matthews ([Dan
Ziskie](/wiki/Dan_Ziskie "Dan Ziskie")) to resign so he can run for the office
he previously held, Governor of Pennsylvania, the race being wide open
following Russo's death. In the season finale, "Chapter 13", Underwood is
appointed Vice President to replace Matthews.[47]

### Season
2[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Frank_Underwood_\(House_of_Cards\)&action=edit&section=14
"Edit section: Season 2")]

Main article: [House of Cards (season 2)](/wiki/House_of_Cards_\(season_2\)
"House of Cards \(season 2\)")

"There are two types of vice presidents: doormats and Matadors. Which do you
think I intend to be?"

— Underwood[36]

Underwood assumes the position of [Vice President of the United
States](/wiki/Vice_President_of_the_United_States "Vice President of the
United States"). Over the course of the season, he "faces challenges from
similarly ambitious businessmen, the Chinese government and Congress itself"
as he continues to pursue his political aspirations.[48] His plotline revolves
around battles with billionaire Raymond Tusk ([Gerald
McRaney](/wiki/Gerald_McRaney "Gerald McRaney")), involving Chinese [money
laundering](/wiki/Money_laundering "Money laundering"). Over the course of the
season his biggest challenges are the institutional power of the Office of the
President and Tusk's power as a billionaire industrialist.[49]

He finds new rivals in Tusk, who seeks to maintain his position as Walker's
right-hand adviser against Underwood's intrusion, and his former
communications director, Remy Danton ([Mahershala Ali](/wiki/Mahershala_Ali
"Mahershala Ali")), who is now a lobbyist working with Tusk.[36]

At the beginning of the season, Underwood is trying to erase all links to
Russo's death.[50] Thus, he kills Barnes by shoving her in front of an
oncoming [Washington Metro](/wiki/Washington_Metro "Washington Metro")
train,[51] and frames her colleague and lover Lucas Goodwin ([Sebastian
Arcelus](/wiki/Sebastian_Arcelus "Sebastian Arcelus")) for
[cyberterrorism](/wiki/Cyberterrorism "Cyberterrorism"). Another early task
for newly promoted Underwood is finding his own replacement as House Majority
Whip. He supports Jacqueline Sharp ([Molly Parker](/wiki/Molly_Parker "Molly
Parker")), a military veteran and third-term Representative from California,
although he refrains from offering public backing.[52]

Toward the end of the season, Underwood orchestrates Walker's downfall. He
secretly leaks the details of the money laundering, for which Walker is
blamed. While publicly supporting Walker, Underwood works behind the scenes to
have him [impeached](/wiki/Articles_of_impeachment "Articles of impeachment"),
with Sharp's help. In the season finale, "Chapter 26", Walker resigns, and
Underwood succeeds him as President of the United States.[13]

### Season
3[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Frank_Underwood_\(House_of_Cards\)&action=edit&section=15
"Edit section: Season 3")]

Main article: [House of Cards (season 3)](/wiki/House_of_Cards_\(season_3\)
"House of Cards \(season 3\)")

"When they bury me, it won't be in my backyard, and when they come to pay
their respects, they'll have to wait in line."

— Underwood[53]

Season 3 begins with Underwood's presidency off to a rocky start: six months
into his term, he is unpopular with the public, and Congress is blocking his
attempts to move legislation forward. He plans to secure his legacy with an
ambitious jobs bill, America Works, but the Democratic Congressional
leadership refuses to support it; they also tell him that they will not
support him if he seeks the presidential nomination in the next election. He
nominates Claire for [United States Ambassador to the United
Nations](/wiki/United_States_Ambassador_to_the_United_Nations "United States
Ambassador to the United Nations"), but her nomination is defeated after she
makes a gaffe during a Senate nomination hearing.[8]

Underwood announces that he will not run for reelection, and advocates for
America Works, which he intends to pay for by stripping entitlement programs.
He fails to get the bill through Congress and uses that as a reason to renege
on his promise to not run in 2016. Solicitor General Heather Dunbar
([Elizabeth Marvel](/wiki/Elizabeth_Marvel "Elizabeth Marvel")) announces that
she will seek the presidential nomination, and actually gives Underwood a
battle. Underwood convinces Sharp to get married so she can announce her
candidacy, for the sole reason of sapping women’s votes from Dunbar, at which
point she will withdraw and accept the nomination for VP. After the
presidential debate, in which Underwood publicly humiliates Sharp in order to
go after Dunbar, Sharp retaliates by backing Dunbar's campaign. Ultimately,
however, Underwood wins the [Iowa caucuses](/wiki/Iowa_caucuses "Iowa
caucuses").[54]

Meanwhile, the Underwoods' marriage is faltering. Underwood gives Claire the
ambassador job in a [recess appointment](/wiki/Recess_appointment "Recess
appointment"), but she is forced to resign in order to solve a diplomatic
crisis. Claire begins to question whether she still loves her husband, and
they get into an ugly fight in which he tells her that she is nothing without
him. Season 3 ends with Claire leaving Underwood as he prepares for the [New
Hampshire primary](/wiki/New_Hampshire_primary "New Hampshire
primary").[55][56]

### Season
4[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Frank_Underwood_\(House_of_Cards\)&action=edit&section=16
"Edit section: Season 4")]

Main article: [House of Cards (season 4)](/wiki/House_of_Cards_\(season_4\)
"House of Cards \(season 4\)")

"That's right, we don't submit to terror. We _make_ the terror."

— Underwood[57]

Underwood trails Dunbar in the polls, eventually losing the New Hampshire
primary. Realizing that he needs Claire to win, he persuades her to come back
by promising to support her run for a congressional district in Texas.
However, he sandbags her prospective candidacy by endorsing a political ally's
daughter, in order to keep Claire focused on his campaign. On the day of the
[South Carolina primary](/wiki/South_Carolina_primary "South Carolina
primary"), Claire retaliates by arranging for two compromising photos to be
leaked: one of Underwood's father with a [Klansman](/wiki/Klu_Klux_Klan "Klu
Klux Klan"), and one of Underwood posing with a Confederate Civil War re-
enactor. Underwood deduces that Claire was behind the leaks, and confronts
her. Claire calmly admits what she did, and puts forth a proposition: that she
run as his vice president. He angrily rejects the idea.

Lucas Goodwin is released from prison and, seeking revenge for Barnes' death,
shoots Underwood at a campaign rally, hitting him in the liver. He also
mortally wounds Meechum, who manages to kill him before succumbing to his
injuries. Underwood is rushed to the hospital for immediate surgery, and falls
into a coma. It is soon discovered that he needs a liver transplant. Stamper
manages to bump him to the top of the transplant list, and he survives. Once
he recovers, he agrees to let Claire run as his vice president.

Dunbar drops out of the race due to the discovery of a meeting she'd had with
Goodwin a few days before the attempt on Underwood's life. Underwood begins
planning to maneuver Claire into the VP spot and to use the
[NSA](/wiki/National_Security_Agency "National Security Agency") to illegally
obtain voter information and spy on the Republican nominee, Will Conway ([Joel
Kinnaman](/wiki/Joel_Kinnaman "Joel Kinnaman")). This happens while Underwood
and Claire advocate for a controversial gun control bill for the sole purpose
of creating an atmosphere divisive enough to weed out potential running mates.
During the resulting [open convention](/wiki/Brokered_convention "Brokered
convention"), Underwood intimidates the front-runner, Secretary of State
Catherine Durant ([Jayne Atkinson](/wiki/Jayne_Atkinson "Jayne Atkinson")),
into surrendering her delegates, and uses the public sympathy from Claire's
mother's death to ensure that he and Claire are nominated.[58]

When American extremists loyal to the [terrorist](/wiki/Terrorist "Terrorist")
group Islamic Caliphate Organization (ICO) kidnap a suburban family, Underwood
allows Conway to negotiate with them, making his opponent look like a hero -
and then releases NSA data that proves Conway illegally influenced Congress.
Soon afterward, however, Underwood is hit with two crises at once: ICO's
leader orders his followers to kill one of the hostages, while journalist Tom
Hammerschmidt ([Boris McGiver](/wiki/Boris_McGiver "Boris McGiver")) exposes
Underwood's crimes in the _Washington Herald_. Facing disgrace and possible
[impeachment](/wiki/Impeachment "Impeachment"), Underwood decides to declare
war on ICO and allow the public to see the hostage die in order to distract
from the scandal and create an atmosphere of widespread fear that he and
Claire can exploit in the weeks before the election.[58][59]

### Season
5[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Frank_Underwood_\(House_of_Cards\)&action=edit&section=17
"Edit section: Season 5")]

"The American people don't know what's best for them. I do. I know exactly
what they need. They're like little children, Claire, children we never had.
We have to hold their sticky fingers and wipe their filthy mouths. Teach them
right from wrong. Tell them what to think and how to feel and what to want.
They even help writing their wildest dreams, crafting their worst fears. Lucky
for them, they have me, they have you. Underwood, Underwood, 2016. 2020. 2024.
2028. 2032. 2036. One nation, Underwood."

— Underwood[60]

In the days before the election, Underwood pushes Congress to formally declare
war on ICO, and orders the CIA to kill one of the terrorists and make it look
like he had died fleeing capture. Underwood still lags in the polls, however,
and on election night it appears he is going to lose to Conway. With help from
Stamper and campaign strategist LeAnn Harvey ([Neve
Campbell](/wiki/Neve_Campbell "Neve Campbell")), Underwood has NSA contractor
Aidan Macallan ([Damian Young](/wiki/Damian_Young "Damian Young")) stage a
[cyberattack](/wiki/Cyberattack "Cyberattack") on several election stations.
He also uses the fear of a possible terrorist attack to pressure the governors
of Tennessee and Ohio to halt voting. The tactics work; the two states refuse
to declare a winner, and the election drags on unresolved for several weeks.

The presidency is finally set to be decided by a [contingent
election](/wiki/Contingent_election "Contingent election") in the House.
Neither Underwood nor Conway receive enough votes, however, so Underwood
appoints Claire Acting President until the House votes again. Underwood tries
to convince Arizona Congressman Alex Romero ([James
Martinez](/wiki/James_Martinez_\(actor\) "James Martinez \(actor\)")) to vote
in his favor, but when Underwood refuses to help him with his own agenda,
Romero forms a committee to impeach him.

The Underwoods blackmail Conway's influential campaign manager Mark Usher
([Campbell Scott](/wiki/Campbell_Scott "Campbell Scott")) into joining their
side by threatening to release recordings of Conway berating a pilot and his
running mate Ted Brockhart ([Colm Feore](/wiki/Colm_Feore "Colm Feore"))
threatening to kill Frank. Once Usher begins working for them, they release
the tapes anyway, which costs Conway the election. Underwood is now
[President-elect](/wiki/President-elect "President-elect"), but his past comes
back to haunt him once again when Hammerschmidt begins investigating Zoe
Barnes' death, convinced it was not an accident. Underwood and Claire nip any
potential story in the bud by convincing Stamper to "confess" to murdering
Barnes.

When Romero's committee intensifies its investigation, Underwood tries to
divert their attention by ordering troops into [Syria](/wiki/Syria "Syria") on
the pretense of preventing a terrorist attack. This provokes Durant to testify
against him; before she can take the stand, however, Underwood pushes her down
a flight of stairs, incapacitating her. When Walker testifies about
Underwood's role in the Chinese money laundering, Underwood takes the stand in
his own defense and stuns the committee by resigning the presidency. When
Claire demands an explanation, Underwood reveals that his resignation was part
of a plan to ensure that they control the country for years to come: Claire
from the White House, he from the private sector. To tie up loose ends, he has
Macallan and Harvey killed.

For Underwood's plan to work, however, Claire has to
[pardon](/wiki/Presidential_pardon "Presidential pardon") him and Stamper,
which would damage her credibility with the public. Claire promises him that
she will grant the pardons, but makes no mention of them during her first
address to the nation as president. Angered, Underwood calls her several
times, but each time he gets her [voicemail](/wiki/Voicemail "Voicemail"),
causing him to worry that she has abandoned him. He breaks the fourth wall and
says, "If she doesn't pardon me, I'll kill her."

## Critical
response[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Frank_Underwood_\(House_of_Cards\)&action=edit&section=18
"Edit section: Critical response")]

### Season
1[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Frank_Underwood_\(House_of_Cards\)&action=edit&section=19
"Edit section: Season 1")]

_[The New York Times](/wiki/The_New_York_Times "The New York Times")'_ [David
Itzkoff](/wiki/David_Itzkoff "David Itzkoff") called Underwood a "scheming
politician" who does "some of the most evil and underhanded things
imaginable".[61] [Brian Stelter](/wiki/Brian_Stelter "Brian Stelter") of _[The
New York Times](/wiki/The_New_York_Times "The New York Times")_ said Underwood
"…is on a quest for power that’s just as suspenseful as anything on
television."[7] _[New York Daily News](/wiki/Daily_News_\(New_York\) "Daily
News \(New York\)")_ critic Don Kaplan says "…conniving Congressman Frank
Underwood, is easily one of the most complex antiheroes on TV — except he’s
not on TV".[62] David Wiegand of the _[San Francisco
Chronicle](/wiki/San_Francisco_Chronicle "San Francisco Chronicle")_ describes
the character as one who "all but salivates over the chance to use his
considerable power to gain more power, especially if it involves pulling the
rug out from under some colleagues and the wool over the eyes of others."[63]

[Andrew Davies](/wiki/Andrew_Davies_\(writer\) "Andrew Davies \(writer\)"),
the producer of the original UK TV series, feels that Underwood lacks the
"charm" of the original character, [Francis Urquhart](/wiki/Francis_Urquhart
"Francis Urquhart").[28]

_[The Independent](/wiki/The_Independent "The Independent")_ praised Spacey's
portrayal as a more "menacing" character, "hiding his rage behind Southern
charm and old-fashioned courtesy,"[16] while _[The New
Republic](/wiki/The_New_Republic "The New Republic")_ noted that "When
Urquhart addressed the audience, it was partly in the spirit of conspiratorial
fun. His [asides](/wiki/Asides "Asides") sparked with wit. He wasn't just
ruthlessly striving, he was amusing himself, mocking the ridiculousness of his
milieu. There is no impishness about Spacey’s Frank Underwood, just numb,
machine-like ambition. Even his affection for his wife is a calculation."[15]

Poniewozik praises Underwood's accent, saying "Spacey gives Underwood a silky
Southern accent you could pour over crushed ice and sip with a sprig of mint
on Derby Day."[24] [Nancy deWolf Smith](/wiki/Nancy_deWolf_Smith "Nancy deWolf
Smith") of _[The Wall Street Journal](/wiki/The_Wall_Street_Journal "The Wall
Street Journal")_ describes the accent as a "mild but sometimes missing
Carolina accent".[32] _Time_ listed Frank Underwood among the 11 most
influential fictional characters in 2013.[64]

### Season
2[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Frank_Underwood_\(House_of_Cards\)&action=edit&section=20
"Edit section: Season 2")]

According to _[The Kansas City Star](/wiki/The_Kansas_City_Star "The Kansas
City Star")_ 's Smith, "Frank hasn’t changed, and neither has his brand of
Machiavellian political theater" and "Spacey has lost none of his smarmy
magnetism as the cartoon-ish villain".[36] According to
_[Variety](/wiki/Variety_\(magazine\) "Variety \(magazine\)")_ 's Brian Lowry,
"Kevin Spacey’s showy performance as an unscrupulous politician" is foremost
among the show's strengths, but the show's weakness is the "failure to present
its scheming protagonist with equally matched foes".[65] Lowry feels that as
conniving as Underwood is, it is unfathomable that "nobody else in a town
built on power seems particularly adept at recognizing this or combating
him".[65] Goodman says "Spacey is nothing if not constantly magnetic".[25] The
delayed use of the fourth wall is perceived as clever.[25] Alison Willmore of
[Indiewire](/wiki/Indiewire "Indiewire") says that "Unlike [Walter
White](/wiki/Walter_White_\(Breaking_Bad\) "Walter White \(Breaking Bad\)") or
[Tony Soprano](/wiki/Tony_Soprano "Tony Soprano"), Frank feels at peace with
his ruthless pragmatism and what he does in pursuit of power, and reminds us
of the fact in his asides to the camera...he may be a ruthless
[sociopath](/wiki/Antisocial_personality_disorder "Antisocial personality
disorder"), but there's something to admire there".[66] However Willmore noted
that Frank became lighter in season 2 noting that the season was "...delivered
with more of a wink by Frank than before."[66]

Poniewozik notes that "It also remains a delight to watch Spacey pump the
humid breath of life into House of Cards’ arid Capitol chill. If only his
character weren’t so dominant of his surroundings as well. One reason the
series’ movements can feel so mechanical is that, so far, no one seems nearly
in Underwood’s league: not the adversaries he battles directly, nor the sad
sacks that he gulls without their even knowing it."[18] Chuck Barney of the
_[San Jose Mercury News](/wiki/San_Jose_Mercury_News "San Jose Mercury News")_
notes that the preview episodes show that "Frank's
"[Survivor](/wiki/Survivor_\(US_TV_series\) "Survivor \(US TV series\)")"-like
back-stabbing is beginning to feel a bit repetitive." and that his lack of an
adversarial foil has become an issue: "...things always seem to fall neatly
into place for him. Even his showdowns with the president ([Michel
Gill](/wiki/Michel_Gill "Michel Gill")) come off as one-sided..."[67] Verne
Gay of _[Newsday](/wiki/Newsday "Newsday")_ notes that "Frank Underwood has no
remorse, no superannuated sense of Washington tradition or decorum, and
certainly no second thoughts. He is TV's perfect monster of the moment - a
compleat malefactor, with a pleasing honey-toned drawl."[68]

[Alessandra Stanley](/wiki/Alessandra_Stanley "Alessandra Stanley") of _[The
New York Times](/wiki/The_New_York_Times "The New York Times")_ says "By
positing a Johnsonesque power broker and master schemer who wields cabalistic
influence behind the scenes, _House of Cards_ assigns order and purpose to
what, in real life, is too often just an endless, baffling tick-tack-toe
stalemate."[69] [NPR](/wiki/NPR "NPR")'s Eric Deggans says that Underwood
"blends velvety charm and mesmerizing menace like no other character on
television".[70]

_[New York Observer](/wiki/New_York_Observer "New York Observer")_ critic Drew
Grant notes that although the series aired during the golden age of dramatic
antiheroes, Underwood's villainy has become trite: "House of Cards is a good
reminder, however, that there is a reason [Iago](/wiki/Iago "Iago") wasn’t the
center of _[Othello](/wiki/Othello "Othello")_. Unrelenting, unexplained
cruelty can be as pedantic as constant kindness."[71]

Spacey's portrayal was not without detractors: _[Hitfix](/wiki/Hitfix
"Hitfix")_ reviewer [Alan Sepinwall](/wiki/Alan_Sepinwall "Alan Sepinwall")
accused him of "hamming it up" and "phoning it in on a not very good show to
begin with".[72]

### Season
3[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Frank_Underwood_\(House_of_Cards\)&action=edit&section=21
"Edit section: Season 3")]

Reviews for season 3 of _House of Cards_ were mostly positive. However, a few
critics found the Underwood character was becoming repetitive: the critical
consensus on the review aggregation site [Rotten
Tomatoes](/wiki/Rotten_Tomatoes "Rotten Tomatoes") held that, "Season three
introduces intriguing new political and personal elements to Frank Underwood's
character, even if it feels like more of the same for some."[73] Ed Power of
_[The Daily Telegraph](/wiki/The_Daily_Telegraph "The Daily Telegraph")_
wrote, "Everyone in House of Cards has an agenda - a secret twitching in the
attic. The thrill, and the horror, may lie in the degree to which we catch
reflections of real life in its dark, cool contours." [74]

Some critics opined that the Underwood character is less interesting once he
achieves his goal of becoming president and actually has to govern. "You could
take the show seriously just as long as you didn’t have to take it seriously,
as long as it only took place in the dream world of imaginary fantasy
politics," wrote Aaron Bady of _[The New Republic](/wiki/The_New_Republic "The
New Republic")_ , who compared Underwood unfavorably with [Josiah
Bartlett](/wiki/Josiah_Bartlett "Josiah Bartlett") of _[The West
Wing](/wiki/The_West_Wing "The West Wing")_. "But when a cartoon becomes
president, it starts to look too fake to be real, but too real to be a
cartoon. Frank plays the role of President Bartlett, a cartoon president doing
things that would actually, in reality, be kind of great. But Bartlett was too
good to be true, and the old Frank was too evil to be true. President
Underwood is just too dull to be a fantasy, and so the props take center
stage."[3]

Critics continued to praise Spacey's performance, however. Don Kaplan of _[The
New York Daily News](/wiki/The_New_York_Daily_News "The New York Daily News")_
wrote, "Underwood’s bottomless appetite for dark dealing keeps Spacey so
deliciously detestable you can’t help but keep rooting for the bad guy to
win." [75]

### Season
4[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Frank_Underwood_\(House_of_Cards\)&action=edit&section=22
"Edit section: Season 4")]

In season 4, Jacob Solworthy wrote in his review of the first six episodes of
season four: "Until now, 'House of Cards' has centred on the character's
outward expression of power -- not to mention his hunger for it -- but the
writers have shrewdly stripped that back, instead focusing on the character's
internal fears in a way not dissimilar from [Tony](/wiki/Tony_Soprano "Tony
Soprano")'s dream sequences in '[The Sopranos](/wiki/The_Sopranos "The
Sopranos")'," he later added, "You'll never root for Frank more than you do by
the end of these six episodes."[76]

On the other hand, Daniel Fienberg from _[The Hollywood
Reporter](/wiki/The_Hollywood_Reporter "The Hollywood Reporter")_ was critical
of Spacey's performance, writing: " Spacey's performance, which at least had
an appealingly theatrical extravagance when the series began, has grown less
enjoyable. Having reached a pinnacle, there's no way to root for Frank's
striving anymore, if you ever were, but House of Cards has yet to commit to
urging us to root for Frank's downfall."[77]

There was also considerable mention of the evolution of Underwood's
relationship with Claire. "[T]heir partnership has morphed into an entirely
professional exercise, with a shared lust for power having supplanted more
conventional matrimonial bonds," wrote Brian Lowry of
_[Variety](/wiki/Variety_\(magazine\) "Variety \(magazine\)")_.[58] _[The
Atlantic](/wiki/The_Atlantic_\(magazine\) "The Atlantic \(magazine\)")_ 's
Spencer Kornhaber remarked, however, that the utter ruthlessness displayed by
Underwoods in the season finale may have represented a "[jump the
shark](/wiki/Jump_the_shark "Jump the shark")" moment for the series:

> The Underwoods have murdered a politician and a journalist, and some
> innocents have also been collateral damage to their activities. Now, though,
> they've set out to maintain their power at the cost of mass casualties.
> Netflix hasn't said how many seasons are to come, but it's hard to imagine
> the show being watchable for all that much longer now that this rubicon of
> despicability has been crossed.[78]

Some compared Underwood's story line in season 4 to the [2016 U.S.
presidential election](/wiki/United_States_presidential_election,_2016 "United
States presidential election, 2016").[79] Brian Moyland of _[The
Guardian](/wiki/The_Guardian_\(newspaper\) "The Guardian \(newspaper\)")_
wrote:

> _House of Cards_ has never felt like the real presidency: Frank Underwood is
> evil incarnate, bumping off junior Congressmen and pushing journalists in
> front of trains. But now that, in real life, we're in the throes of such a
> bizarre presidential race, his machinations are starting to look almost
> viable. There are several parallels between Underwood's re-election campaign
> and the 2016 campaigns of [Donald Trump](/wiki/Donald_Trump "Donald Trump"),
> [Ted Cruz](/wiki/Ted_Cruz "Ted Cruz"), [Hillary
> Clinton](/wiki/Hillary_Clinton "Hillary Clinton") and [Bernie
> Sanders](/wiki/Bernie_Sanders "Bernie Sanders").[80]

### Awards and
nominations[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Frank_Underwood_\(House_of_Cards\)&action=edit&section=23
"Edit section: Awards and nominations")]

At the [3rd Critics' Choice Television
Awards](/wiki/3rd_Critics%27_Choice_Television_Awards "3rd Critics' Choice
Television Awards"), Spacey was nominated for [Best Actor in a Drama
Series](/wiki/Critics%27_Choice_Television_Award_for_Best_Actor_in_a_Drama_Series
"Critics' Choice Television Award for Best Actor in a Drama Series") for his
portrayal of Underwood.[81]

On July 18, 2013, [Netflix](/wiki/Netflix "Netflix") earned the first
[Primetime Emmy Award](/wiki/Primetime_Emmy_Award "Primetime Emmy Award")
nominations for original online only [web television](/wiki/Web_television
"Web television") for the [65th Primetime Emmy
Awards](/wiki/65th_Primetime_Emmy_Awards "65th Primetime Emmy Awards"). Three
of its [web series](/wiki/Web_series "Web series"), _[Arrested
Development](/wiki/Arrested_Development_\(TV_series\) "Arrested Development
\(TV series\)")_ , _[Hemlock Grove](/wiki/Hemlock_Grove_\(TV_series\) "Hemlock
Grove \(TV series\)")_ , and _House of Cards_ , earned nominations.[31] For
the first time, three [Primetime Emmy](/wiki/Primetime_Emmy_Award "Primetime
Emmy Award") nominations for lead roles were from [web
television](/wiki/Web_television "Web television") series: [Outstanding Lead
Actor in a Drama
Series](/wiki/Primetime_Emmy_Award_for_Outstanding_Lead_Actor_in_a_Drama_Series
"Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Lead Actor in a Drama Series") to Spacey
for his portrayal of Frank Underwood, [Outstanding Lead Actress in a Drama
Series](/wiki/Primetime_Emmy_Award_for_Outstanding_Lead_Actress_in_a_Drama_Series
"Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Lead Actress in a Drama Series") to
[Robin Wright](/wiki/Robin_Wright "Robin Wright") for her portrayal of Claire
Underwood, and [Outstanding Lead Actor in a Comedy
Series](/wiki/Primetime_Emmy_Award_for_Outstanding_Lead_Actor_in_a_Comedy_Series
"Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Lead Actor in a Comedy Series") to
[Jason Bateman](/wiki/Jason_Bateman "Jason Bateman") for his portrayal of
[Michael Bluth](/wiki/Michael_Bluth "Michael Bluth") in _Arrested
Development_.[31] Spacey submitted "[Chapter
1](/wiki/Chapter_1_\(House_of_Cards\) "Chapter 1 \(House of Cards\)")" for
consideration to earn his nomination.[82] Spacey also earned a [Golden Globe
nomination for Best Actor in a Television Series
Drama](/wiki/Golden_Globe_Award_for_Best_Actor_%E2%80%93_Television_Series_Drama
"Golden Globe Award for Best Actor – Television Series Drama") and a [Screen
Actors Guild nomination for Outstanding Performance by a Male Actor in a Drama
Series](/wiki/Screen_Actors_Guild_Award_for_Outstanding_Performance_by_a_Male_Actor_in_a_Drama_Series
"Screen Actors Guild Award for Outstanding Performance by a Male Actor in a
Drama Series") nominations.[83][84]

In season 2, Spacey won the Golden Globe for Best Actor in a Television Series
Drama at the [72nd Golden Globe Awards](/wiki/72nd_Golden_Globe_Awards "72nd
Golden Globe Awards") and Screen Actors Guild Outstanding Performance by a
Male Actor in a Drama Series at the [21st Screen Actors Guild
Awards](/wiki/21st_Screen_Actors_Guild_Awards "21st Screen Actors Guild
Awards"), as well as nominations for Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Lead
Actor in a Drama Series at the [66th Primetime Emmy
Awards](/wiki/66th_Primetime_Emmy_Awards "66th Primetime Emmy Awards") and a
[Screen Actors Guild nomination for Outstanding by an Ensemble in a Drama
Series](/wiki/Screen_Actors_Guild_Award_for_Outstanding_Performance_by_an_Ensemble_in_a_Drama_Series
"Screen Actors Guild Award for Outstanding Performance by an Ensemble in a
Drama Series").[85][86][87][88][89]

In season 3, Spacey was nominated for Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding
Lead Actor in a Drama Series at the [67th Primetime Emmy
Awards](/wiki/67th_Primetime_Emmy_Awards "67th Primetime Emmy Awards"), his
third nomination for the role.[90] He also was nominated for both Outstanding
Performance by a Male Actor in a Drama Series and Outstanding Performance by
an Ensemble in a Drama Series at the [22nd Screen Actors Guild
Awards](/wiki/22nd_Screen_Actors_Guild_Awards "22nd Screen Actors Guild
Awards").[91]

For his performance in season 4, Spacey earned a nomination for Primetime Emmy
Award for Outstanding Lead Actor in a Drama Series at the [68th Primetime Emmy
Awards](/wiki/68th_Primetime_Emmy_Awards "68th Primetime Emmy Awards").[92]

For his performance in season 5, Spacey received his fifth consecutive
Primetime Emmy Award for Outstianding Lead Actor in a Drama Series nomination
for the [69th Primetime Emmy Awards](/wiki/69th_Primetime_Emmy_Awards "69th
Primetime Emmy Awards").[93]
